pullRequest.body:
Defines the normal form of meromorphic functions and provides API for continuous extension, as discussed [on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/API.20for.20continuous.20extension.20of.20meromorphic.20functions). More material will be provided in upcoming PRs.

This material is used in [Project VD](https://github.com/kebekus/ProjectVD), which aims to formalize Value Distribution Theory for meromorphic functions on the complex plane.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [f800bacb4e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22867/commits/f800bacb4ef17e9857fed2391cc6150f89780762)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.Meromorphic.NormalFormAt` (new file)|1649|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ AnalyticAt.MeromorphicNFAt`
`+ MeromorphicAt.MeromorphicNFAt_of_toNF`
`+ MeromorphicAt.meromorphicNFAt_iff`
`+ MeromorphicAt.toNF`
`+ MeromorphicAt.toNF_id_on_complement`
`+ MeromorphicAt.toNF_id_on_nhdNE`
`+ MeromorphicNFAt`
`+ MeromorphicNFAt.analyticAt`
`+ MeromorphicNFAt.meromorphicAt`
`+ MeromorphicNFAt.toNF_eq_id`
`+ eventuallyEq_nhdNE_iff_eventuallyEq_nhd`
`+ eventuallyEq_nhds_of_eventuallyEq_nhdsNE`
`+ meromorphicNFAt_congr`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
I think this name should swap its components, since the NE is on the LHS of the iff.
Upsetting. Fixed.

```suggestion
or if it can locally be written as `fun z ↦ (z - x) ^ n • g` where `g` is
```

```suggestion
    (∃ (n : ℤ), ∃ g : 𝕜 → E, (AnalyticAt 𝕜 g x) ∧ (g x ≠ 0) ∧ (f =ᶠ[𝓝 x] (· - x) ^ n • g )) :=
  Iff.rfl
```

or
```suggestion
    (∃ (n : ℤ), ∃ g : 𝕜 → E, (AnalyticAt 𝕜 g x) ∧ (g x ≠ 0) ∧ (f =ᶠ[𝓝 x] (· - x) ^ n • g)) :=
  .rfl
```

```suggestion
there, or if it has a pole at `x` and takes the default value `0`. -/
```

You have a lot of unnecessary brackets. Also your indenting is a bit confusing
```suggestion
  f =ᶠ[𝓝 x] 0 ∨
    ∃ (n : ℤ) (g : 𝕜 → E), AnalyticAt 𝕜 g x ∧ g x ≠ 0 ∧ f =ᶠ[𝓝 x] (· - x) ^ n • g
```

This is already the equation lemma. You know you can do `rw [MeromorphicNFAt]`, right?
```suggestion
```

```suggestion
    MeromorphicNFAt f x ↔ AnalyticAt 𝕜 f x ∨ hf.order < 0 ∧ f x = 0 := by
```

Isn't this true as
```suggestion
theorem MeromorphicAt.meromorphicNFAt_iff :
    MeromorphicNFAt f x ↔ MeromorphicAt f x ∧ (AnalyticAt 𝕜 f x ∨ hf.order < 0 ∧ f x = 0) := by
```

This is probably true, and might well be useful … but I fear the compiler will reject your formulation because `hf.order` is not defined. There must be a way to fix that, but I cannot formulate something that compiles. Please advise.

Here it is:
```suggestion
theorem MeromorphicAt.meromorphicNFAt_iff :
    MeromorphicNFAt f x ↔ AnalyticAt 𝕜 f x ∨ ∃ hf : MeromorphicAt f x, hf.order < 0 ∧ f x = 0 := by
```
but really `MeromorphicAt.order` should take `f` as an argument and return a junk value if `f` isn't meromorphic
Roger. I implemented your suggestion. I tend to not touch `MeromorphicAt.order` unless this has been discussed on Zulip with the people who introduced it…

```suggestion
    f =ᶠ[𝓝[≠] z₀] g ↔ f =ᶠ[𝓝 z₀] g := by
```

Don't you need only assume one of the functions is analytic?
```suggestion
theorem eventuallyEq_nhdNE_iff_eventuallyEq_nhd (hf : AnalyticAt 𝕜 f z₀) :
  f =ᶠ[𝓝[≠] z₀] g ↔ f =ᶠ[𝓝 z₀] g := by
```

I think you need both. For a counterexample, take `f = 0` and take `g` as the indicator function of a point. Then, `f` is analytic and the two agree in a punctured neighbourhood, but in no regular neighbourhood of that point.

So you can get away with
```suggestion
theorem eventuallyEq_nhdNE_iff_eventuallyEq_nhd (hf : AnalyticAt 𝕜 f z₀) (hg : ContinuousAt 𝕜 g z₀) :
    f =ᶠ[𝓝[≠] z₀] g ↔ f =ᶠ[𝓝 z₀] g := by
```
right? I'm thinking it might be useful as a way to prove analycity of `g` knowing only analycity of `f`
I see what you are saying. Going further down that line, it will suffice to assume continuity for `f` as well. Let me see if I can work this out before going to the office.

pullRequest.title: feat: API for continuous extension of meromorphic functions
